titlestmt.titleproper: A Guide to the Grand Teton Lodge Company Records FA423
titlestmt.author: Regina Carra

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on 2024-03-13 14:20:00 -0400.

physdesc.extent: 29 legal document boxes, 1 card file box, and 2 flat file folders

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Rockefeller Archive Center has title, copyright, and literary rights in the collection, in so far as it holds them, and has authority to grant permission to cite and publish archival material from the collection.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Grand Teton Lodge Company records were donated to the Rockefeller Archive Center in August 2003, by GTLC president Clay James.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Related materials will be found in other Rockefeller Archive Center collections, including the Harold P. Fabian papers; the Kenneth Chorley papers; and the Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Cultural Interests series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Grand Teton Lodge Company records consist of board materials, correspondence files, and financial records that document the company's operations in Grand Teton National Park from the 1930s to the 1980s. The bulk of the materials, dating from the late 1940s to the 1960s, concerns the development and renovation of tourist and lodging facilities in the park, and particularly the design, construction, furnishing, and remodeling of the new Jackson Lake Lodge, the cabins and facilities at Colter Bay, and the Jenny Lake Lodge.

Topics covered include the development of the park and the lodges. Early materials concerning the organization of the Grand Teton Lodge Company, concessions operations, and negotiations with the National Park Service and state representatives, are found in Harold Fabian's correspondence files from the 1930s-1940s, labeled Moran Operations and Jackson Hole. National Park Service files touch on the extension of Grand Teton National Park and the monument controversy, but also include studies of park development, concessions financing, and a 1965 survey of concession facilities in neighboring Yellowstone National Park. Other materials relating to interactions with the National Park Service, 1948-1950, are found in files for the GTLC's parent organization, Jackson Hole Preserve, Inc. The records also include JHPI board meeting materials for 1953-1969.

Files relating to the Lodge Company operations include accounting, construction, and general management and operations files; correspondence with architects and contractors; correspondence with Rockefeller or JHPI associates in New York, especially Allston Boyer and Kenneth Chorley; files concerning publicity and opening arrangements; and materials relating to transportation and other concession agreements. There is also a nearly full run of financial statements and/or audit reports for the period 1934-1985.

arrangement.head: Arrangement

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Grand Teton Lodge and Transportation Company was formed in 1936, following on a reorganization of the Teton Investment Company. Until their 1936 merger, the Teton Investment Company had been comprised of the Teton Lodge Company and the Teton Transportation Company, known collectively as the Teton Companies. The Transportation Company operated a bus service between Jackson Hole, the Union Pacific Railroad in Victor, Idaho, and Yellowstone Park, whereas the Lodge Company operated the Teton Lodge at Moran and subsequently the old Jackson Lake Lodge.

The Teton Companies were formed in the early 1930s, under the oversight of Harold Fabian, to provide transportation and lodging for visitors to the Grand Tetons. Harold Fabian's involvement in the region had begun a few years earlier with his appointment as vice president of the Snake River Land Company, an organization established in 1927 to provide for John D. Rockefeller Jr.'s land purchases in the Jackson Hole valley. The Snake River Land Company's purchases came with buildings as well as the land, and having acquired the two main lodges in the valley, it found itself in turn the main provider of services for visitors.

John D. Rockefeller Jr. had traveled to the Grand Teton area in 1924 and 1926 under the guidance of Yellowstone National Park Superintendent Harold Albright, and the visit inspired him to preserve the beauty of the region from unregulated development. The 1929 borders of Grand Teton National Park included the mountain range and the lakes abutting it, but they did not safeguard the surrounding valley. Under the guise of the Snake River Land Company, JDR Jr. bought up over 30,000 acres of private land within the Jackson Hole valley, for the express purpose of donating it to the federal government for an expanded Grand Teton National Park.

JDR Jr.'s efforts to donate his land met with prolonged local opposition. In 1943, President Roosevelt circumvented opposition by proclaiming much of the Jackson Hole valley a national monument. It was not until 1949 that Laurance S. Rockefeller was able to complete the formal transfer of land to the National Park Service. In 1950, a new, enlarged Grand Teton National Park emerged, combining the 1929 park and the monument lands.

With the rise in automobile travel and tourism in the postwar period, the park saw an increasing number of visitors, along with changes in the patterns of tourism. While protecting the valley from overdevelopment, there was also a need to provide additional and improved facilities for park visitors. Working through Jackson Hole Preserve Inc. (JHPI), the nonprofit conservation and education organization they founded in 1940, John D. Rockefeller Jr. and his son Laurance provided much of the funding needed to expand and improve tourist facilities in the park. JHPI purchased the Grand Teton Lodge Company, which then became a subsidiary of the nonprofit organization. The Lodge Company's leases with the National Park Service also made it the primary concessioner within the park.

In 1952 the Rockefellers and JHPI began planning and construction for a new Jackson Lake Lodge, which opened in 1955 as the first modern lodge within a national park. A second development at Colter Bay, funded jointly by the National Park Service and the Grand Teton Lodge Company, opened in 1957 and provided a range of accommodations, from rustic cabins (which had been preserved and moved from several locations within the park) to tent and trailer camping, as well as a cafeteria, general store, laundry, service station, marina, and museum. Colter Bay was an important pilot project in the National Park Service's Mission 66 program.
Grand Teton Lodge Company also developed a third lodge at Jenny Lake, on the site of the old Danny Ranch. Jenny Lake Lodge was a smaller and higher-end development of rustic cabins.

In 1955 the Grand Teton Lodge Company dropped the "and Transportation" function from its title, reflecting its heightened role in providing facilities for visitors who tended to prolong their stay in the valley and park.

physdesc.extent: 8 legal document boxes and 2 flat file folders

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Board of Directors series is arranged into four sets of files: Agenda, Correspondence, Minutes, and Executive Committee. Each file heading is arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Board of Directors series documents the general administration of the Grand Teton Lodge Company from the mid-1940s to the mid-1980s.

The series is sorted by file type, but there is a considerable amount of overlap in the contents of the various Board files. The Agenda files for the most part include the full set of materials prepared for the board meetings. The Correspondence files concern meeting scheduling and arrangements and include a mixture of board materials.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Agendas include meeting topics and materials

4 pictures of remodeling at Jackson Lake Lodge

physdesc.extent: 18 legal document boxes and 2 flat file folders

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Grand Teton Lodge Company series is arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The main topics of this series include the development of concessions and tourist facilities, operations, business and accounting, and correspondence.
While files relating to a specific person or place may have their own heading, related documents may also be found under more general titles.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Barton became treasurer of the Grand Teton Lodge Company in 1967. (The folder pre-dates this appointment).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The file contains photocopies of photos of cabins at Colter Bay, Moran, Jackson Lake Lodge, and Square G Ranch.
